campaign.description: How to use AI for content creation without sounding generic

slides.title: AI Content Reality

content.headline: AI Can Write Your Marketing
content.subhead: But there's a right way and a wrong way

slides.narration: AI can write your marketing content. Blog posts, social media, emails, descriptions—all of it. But here's what nobody tells you: there's a right way and a wrong way to use AI for content. The wrong way sounds generic and robotic. The right way sounds like you, but takes a fraction of the time.

slides.title: The Generic Problem

content.headline: Why Most AI Content Sounds the Same

problems.result: Vague claims instead of real details

content.example_bad: We are committed to providing excellent service to our valued customers...
content.example_good: We've been fixing cars in Springfield since 1987. My dad started this shop, and we still treat every customer like family.

slides.narration: Why does most AI content sound the same? No context—the AI doesn't know your business, so it writes generic content. No voice guidance—it defaults to corporate-speak instead of your personality. No specifics—vague claims instead of real details. No editing—first drafts published as final. 'We are committed to providing excellent service' could be anyone. 'We've been fixing cars in Springfield since 1987, my dad started this shop'—that's you.

slides.title: The Right Way

content.headline: How to Get AI Content That Sounds Like You

method.how: Feed it your best content, FAQs, story
Examples of how you talk, words you use
Real names, real numbers, real stories

slides.narration: Here's the right way. Train it on your business—feed it your best existing content, your FAQs, your story. Give it your voice—examples of how you actually talk, words you use, words you don't. Provide specifics—real customer names with permission, real numbers, real stories. Review and refine—spend two to five minutes adding your personal touch. AI writes the draft, you make it yours.

slides.title: The 80/20 Rule
slides.narration: Think of it as eighty-twenty. AI does eighty percent: research, outline, first draft, variations, formatting, SEO optimization. You do twenty percent: add personal stories, include specific details only you know, adjust the tone, give final approval. Without AI, a blog post takes two to four hours. With AI, twenty to thirty minutes. Same quality. Fraction of the time.

slides.title: Content Types AI Handles

content.headline: What AI Can Write for Your Business

slides.narration: What can AI write for your business? Social media posts—daily content, five minutes to review. Blog articles—weekly content, fifteen to twenty minutes to review. Email newsletters—weekly or monthly, ten minutes. Service descriptions—write once, update occasionally. FAQ answers—build a library, five minutes each. Review responses—as needed, two minutes each. Your entire content operation, streamlined.

slides.title: Real Results

case_study.before: 1 blog post per month, 2 social posts per week
case_study.after: 4 blog posts per month, daily social posts
case_study.quote: The AI learned our voice. People comment that they love our personality online—they don't know it's AI-assisted.

slides.narration: Real example. Home cleaning service. Before AI: one blog post a month, two social posts a week, eight hours of work. After AI: four blog posts a month, daily social posts, three hours of work. Results: website traffic up one hundred fifty-six percent, inquiries up forty-three percent. The owner told us: 'The AI learned our voice. People comment that they love our personality online—they don't know it's AI-assisted.'

slides.narration: Ready to create more content in less time? Set up AI content now—we'll train it on your business, your voice, your specifics. Or see sample content first to see what's possible. Either way, you're about to get your time back while publishing more than ever.
